docs.lead_paragraph: The reconciliation package unveiled by Democrats would impose $28 billion in fees on the makers of brand-name drugs over 10 years, $5 billion more than the companies had agreed to in the Senate package. But the nation's drug makers are happy with the health care package over all, and for good reason: the government also would spend an estimated $37.6 billion over 10 years filling a Medicare drug coverage gap known as the doughnut hole.
docs.snippet: The reconciliation package unveiled by Democrats would impose $28 billion in fees on the makers of brand-name drugs over 10 years, $5 billion more than the companies had agreed to in the Senate package.     But the nation's drug makers are happy with...

docs.lead_paragraph: At a rally on Friday at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., President Obama got some of his loudest applause when he talked about a provision in the House reconciliation bill that would allow adult children to remain on their parents' health insurance policies until the age of 27. The provision cited by the president is one of the more significant changes for consumers in the Democrats' health care legislation. Currently, states determine the maximum age until which policies must offer dependent coverage, and the limits vary.

docs.lead_paragraph: On the weekend eve of an historic vote on the health care bill, Republican opponents do not at all sound ready to accept defeat. Or rather, they view defeat as victory, because they can use passage by Democrats, if it happens, as a weapon in the midterm elections. (We've been chronicling all developments on the vote-counting and snags as the House moves toward a vote this coming Sunday on our Prescriptions blog.)

headline.main: BlogTalk: Progressives, Public Option and Abortion

docs.abstract: Progressives are not happy with the health care bill, and some are grudgingly accepting it, while others remain opposed.
docs.snippet: Progressives are not happy with the health care bill, and some are grudgingly accepting it, while others remain opposed.

docs.lead_paragraph: If the health care reform package makes it through Congress, and we should know sometime on Sunday, much of the credit for its salvation will go to Thursday's report from the Congressional Budget Office that, according to The Times's David M. Herszenhorn, predicted "a $940 billion price tag for the new insurance coverage provisions in the bill, and the reduction of future federal deficits of $138 billion over 10 years." It is an article of faith that the budget office resides, pretty much alone among government bodies, in the refined aerie of nonpartisanship, a paragon of technocratic, if not inhuman, objectivity.

headline.main: Checking the Math on Health Care

docs.abstract: Is the Congressional Budget Office a paragon of objectivity, or does it do whatever the majority wants?

docs.lead_paragraph: In the homestretch of the debate over health care, the top question being asked in Washington is whether President Obama and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi have the 216 votes to approve the legislation.
